message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Survey of Path Planning Algorithms for Mobile Robots
Paper Abstract: Path planning algorithms are used by mobile robots, unmanned aerial vehicles, and autonomous cars in order to identify safe, efficient, collision-free, and least-cost travel paths from an origin to a destination. Choosing an appropriate path planning algorithm helps to ensure safe and effective point-to-point navigation, and the optimal algorithm depends on the robot geometry as well as the computing constraints, including static/holonomic and dynamic/non-holonomically-constrained systems, and requires a comprehensive understanding of contemporary solutions. The goal of this paper is to help novice practitioners gain an awareness of the classes of path planning algorithms used today and to understand their potential use cases—particularly within automated or unmanned systems. To that end, we provide broad, rather than deep, coverage of key and foundational algorithms, with popular algorithms and variants considered in the context of different robotic systems. The definitions, summaries, and comparisons are relevant to novice robotics engineers and embedded system developers seeking a primer of available algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of nonholonomic systems:

## Definition

A nonholonomic system in classical mechanics is a physical system with some constraints that are impossible to be cast into the form of holonomic constraints. More specifically, a constraint that cannot be expressed in the form of a function depending only on the coordinates (not on the velocities or any higher-order derivative with respect to time) is a nonholonomic constraint.

## Key Characteristics

Nonholonomic constraints cannot be eliminated by using generalized coordinates. This is an important distinction from holonomic systems, where such constraints can be simplified through coordinate transformations.

A nonholonomic system is often a system where the velocities of the components over time must be known to be able to determine the change of state of the system. In other words, the state of the system depends not just on position, but also on how that position was reached.

## Practical Examples

Examples of nonholonomic systems are Segways, unicycles, and automobiles. Another classic example is the Chaplygin sleigh, which consists of a body that slides frictionlessly on a horizontal plane, with a knife edge that constrains its motion so that the knife slides only longitudinally.(no content)An upright wheel on a plane (sometimes visualized as a unicycle or a rolling upright coin) is a nonholonomic system with a single Pfaffian constraint.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I found comprehensive information about path planning. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

Path planning, also known as the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Approaches

Path planning utilizes several main strategies:

**Grid-Based Approaches**: Traditional grid-based approaches produce paths whose heading changes are constrained to multiples of a given base angle, often resulting in suboptimal paths. Any-angle path planning approaches find shorter paths by propagating information along grid edges (to search fast) without constraining their paths to grid edges (to find short paths).

**Sampling-Based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations. A basic algorithm samples N configurations in C, and retains those in Cfree to use as milestones. A roadmap is then constructed that connects two milestones P and Q if the line segment PQ is completely in Cfree.

## Real-Time Path Planning

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment. This includes everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously takes in information from the surroundings and creates a plan to avoid obstacles.

## Applications

Any-angle path planning are useful for robot navigation and real-time strategy games where more optimal paths are desirable.

I found comprehensive information about mobile robots. Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Basics

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion and is not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Key Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system, with the controller generally being a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots have diverse real-world uses:

- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.
- Specialized equipment may be mounted on robots, allowing them to assist with surgical procedures.

## Research Significance

Mobile robots are a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

The search results also provided detailed information about specific mobile robot platforms (like Khepera, s-bot, and e-puck) and historical developments in the field, including Shakey the Robot, which was the first general-purpose mobile robot able to reason about its own actions.

Web search results for query: "holonomic constraint robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Holonomic constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic_constraints"},{"title":"Nonholonomic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonholonomic_system"},{"title":"Holonomic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holonomic"},{"title":"Pfaffian constraint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pfaffian_constraint"},{"title":"Kinematics equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinematic_equations"},{"title":"Constraint (mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_(mechanics)"},{"title":"Homotopy principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_principle"},{"title":"Lagrangian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_mechanics"},{"title":"Oussama Khatib - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oussama_Khatib"},{"title":"Scleronomous - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scleronomous"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about holonomic constraints in robotics:

## Definition

A holonomic system is a system in which one can deduce the state of a system by knowing only the change of positions of the components of the system over time, but not needing to know the velocity or in what order the components moved relative to each other.

## Examples in Robotics

Examples of holonomic systems are gantry cranes, pendulums, and robotic arms. In contrast, examples of nonholonomic systems are Segways, unicycles, and automobiles.

## Mathematical Framework

Constraint equations of this type are known as holonomic constraints in the study of the dynamics of multi-body systems. More specifically, in robot motion planning, a Pfaffian constraint is a set of k linearly independent constraints linear in velocity, and a Pfaffian constraint is integrable if it is holonomic.

## Key Distinction from Nonholonomic Systems

A nonholonomic system is often a system where the velocities of the components over time must be known to be able to determine the change of state of the system, or a system where a moving part is not able to be bound to a constraint surface. Additionally, in robotics, nonholonomic has been studied in the scope of motion planning and feedback linearization for mobile robots.

I've completed a web search for "autonomous car self-driving." Here's what I found:

## What Are Autonomous/Self-Driving Cars?

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car, driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Historical Development

The history of autonomous vehicles spans decades:

- Cruise control, the first ADAS system, was invented in 1948 by Ralph Teetor.
- The first semi-autonomous car was developed in 1977, by Japan's Tsukuba Mechanical Engineering Laboratory.
- Google began developing its self-driving cars in 2009.

## Current Market Status

Recent developments show varied progress:

- In 2021, Honda was the first manufacturer to sell an SAE Level 3 car, followed by Mercedes-Benz in 2023.
- As of August 2023, vehicles operating at Level 3 and above were an insignificant market factor; as of early 2024, Honda leases a Level 3 car in Japan, and Mercedes sells two Level 3 cars in Germany, California and Nevada.

## Major Players and Recent Changes

Key companies like Waymo and Cruise have been developing robotaxi services, though with mixed results:

- Starting in February 2022, Cruise offered self-driving taxi service in San Francisco, but suspended service in 2023.
- On February 27, 2024, Apple executives made an internal announcement that the entire car project was being cancelled.

I've completed the web search for "unmanned aerial vehicle drone." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Basic Information

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)Its flight is controlled either autonomously by onboard computers or by the remote control of a pilot on the ground or in another vehicle.

## Historical Development

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Modern Applications

UAVs are usually deployed for military and special operation applications, but are also used in a small but growing number of civil applications, such as policing and firefighting, and nonmilitary security work such as surveillance of pipelines.(no content)Firefighters, police, miners, and weather researchers are now using UAVs (commonly referred to as drones), which were first used in military sectors.

## Global Proliferation

By 2013 at least 50 countries used UAVs, with China, Iran, Israel, Pakistan, Turkey, and others designing and building their own varieties.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
